yeah, that screen needs some attention

But ideally icons would be the first column
Most of our other lists have 3-4 columns, but here we have only two of them.
Yeah I get it
Separation between icons and words is worse than any other issue imho

I agree with this.

This is what we do for default streams-
Screenshot-147.png
Thatâ€™s wrong too in my opinion
Yeah, those 2 settings widgets are the ones that have received the least attention over the last few years. I'm not sure what we want to design for them to be, but it should definitely not be that.

@Rohitt Vashishtha and I did an audit of the settings system a few weeks ago on a private stream with a couple other folks chiming in. I have been meaning to publish some general findings to #settings system--I think I posted at least a few high-level things.

I think there's still tons of low-hanging fruit on improving the settings system. I think about 60% of the screens have basically the same shape--some list_render widget plus some UI to add/upload stuff. So somebody who wants to focus on settings can repeat the same sort of holistic audit that we did--it really only took about four hours of pretty intense conversation--and then have a roadmap where they can prioritize from either easiest-to-fix to hardest-to-fix or fix-most-egregious-problems-to-fix-most-subtle-problems.
@Steve Howell we should review our notes and file issues/start more threads anyway after the release.

Yeah, I have been having that in the back of my mind to get back to. When we did the audit a few weeks ago, we sort of agreed that we were a little close to the release to kind of properly scope this a multi-week project. And it would also help to have at least one or two GSOC folks kind of on point for this.

Fortunately, I think we've made some headway on some of the real deep problems--for example, the problems with Users/Deactivated Users/Bots were kinda deep problems, which @Rohitt Vashishtha, @Clara Dantas, and I (and possibly others--sorry if I am forgetting anybody) mostly worked through. So now, for example, we have a path where we possibly simplify the settings system not to have any performance-related hacks for things like calling '/json/users'.
